metadata.titleEn: Integrated environment observation data of base camp in Hulugou sub-basin of Heihe River Basin (2011)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview
The data set of the base camp integrated environmental observation system is a set of ENVIS (IMKO, Germany) which was installed at the base camp observation point by qilian station.It is stored automatically by ENVIS data mining system.
2. Data content
This data set is the scale data from January 1, 2011 to December 31, 2011.It mainly includes two layers of temperature, humidity and wind, six layers of soil water content, precipitation, 5cm geothermal flux, total radiation, seven layers of soil temperature, CO2 and air pressure.
3. Space and time scope
Geographical coordinates: longitude: 99° 53’e;Latitude: 38°16 'N;Height: 2980.2 m
metadata.instructions: Data file name: Daily scale data set. Xlsx of the base camp integrated environmental observation system of hulugou basin in the upper reaches of Heihe River; it can be viewed and edited by WPS or excel.

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earth’s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraine–talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbed–water, water–ice, and ice–air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraine–talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a comprehensive observation system used to monitor cryospheric hydrology in alpine regions?
Example.Answer: The Hulu catchment employs a range of monitoring systems including AWSs that measure meteorological variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and snow depth, along with instruments for soil heat flux, land surface temperature, and soil moisture. Additionally, there are stream-gauging stations for monitoring discharge and various sensors for measuring precipitation and snow depth.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in observing environmental changes in remote alpine regions?
Example.Answer: In remote alpine regions, challenges include significant biases and errors in precipitation observations due to sparse data collection points and the remoteness of these areas, making comprehensive and accurate data collection difficult.

Example.Question: Could you describe an example of a method used to study the effects of land cover changes on water balance in mountainous areas?
Example.Answer: In the Hulu catchment, methods such as the use of runoff fields to study canopy precipitation interception and the deployment of sap flow sensors to estimate transpiration have been used to assess the effects of vegetation pattern changes in vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'comprehensive observation data' in the context of cryospheric hydrology research?
Definition.Answer: In the context of cryospheric hydrology research, 'comprehensive observation data' refers to the collection of extensive and varied environmental data that captures multiple meteorological and hydrological variables such as air temperature, humidity, wind speed, radiation, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation. This data is used to determine hydrological processes and evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on water resources.

Definition.Question: How is 'spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation' defined in research related to mountainous hydrology?
Definition.Answer: The 'spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation' in research related to mountainous hydrology is defined as the variation in precipitation patterns both over different geographical areas (spatial) and time periods (temporal) in alpine regions. Understanding this distribution is crucial for assessing its impact on streamflow and water resources in mountainous areas.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for soil moisture and temperature in alpine regions compare to those used for monitoring snow depth and precipitation?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection for soil moisture and temperature in alpine regions involves long-term monitoring using automated weather stations (AWS) and soil parameter measurements at soil pits, while snow depth is measured using SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors. Precipitation data are collected with rain-weighing sensors and manual comparisons using pit gauges and DFIR gauges. The methods differ in terms of instrumentation and specific environmental conditions they are adapted to monitor.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of automatic microlysimeters for measuring evapotranspiration compare to traditional manual weighing microlysimeters in alpine meteorological studies?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic microlysimeters offer continuous and precise evapotranspiration measurements and were implemented in the CHOICE project, replacing the initial manual weighing microlysimeters. This transition allows for more comprehensive and less labor-intensive data collection, enhancing the temporal resolution of the evapotranspiration data obtained in alpine meteorological studies.

Interpretation.Question: How do the varied meteorological and environmental variables monitored by automated weather stations contribute to understanding the hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The automated weather stations (AWS) monitor a range of meteorological variables including air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. These comprehensive observations help in understanding the hydrological processes by providing data on the interactions between climatic conditions and hydrological responses in mountainous regions.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges and potential solutions associated with measuring precipitation accurately in remote alpine areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Precipitation observations in remote alpine areas face significant biases and errors, particularly due to the remoteness and sparse observations. To address these challenges, intercomparison experiments, such as those referencing the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO, and the use of various gauges like pit gauges and DFIR gauges are employed to improve measurement accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of soil parameter data and hydrological models enhance the understanding of water resource dynamics in arid mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of long-term continuous soil parameter data with hydrological models allows for a more precise simulation of water resource dynamics in arid mountainous regions. This approach helps in assessing the effects of cryospheric and climatic changes on hydrology and enables the prediction of water availability, which is crucial for sustainable water management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of collecting accurate precipitation data in mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable regions such as mountainous areas has posed significant challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the development and use of multiple observational platforms and techniques in collecting environmental data in cryospheric research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The development and use of multiple observational platforms and techniques are driven by the need to gather continuous, accurate data across various environmental factors like air temperature, soil moisture, and snow depth. This is crucial for addressing the identified scientific objectives, such as understanding the spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation and the effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of employing various manual and automatic measurement techniques for capturing meteorological variables on the accuracy and reliability of the data in mountainous cryospheric research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of both manual and automatic measurement techniques, such as those implemented in the comprehensive environmental observation system, can provide a more robust and reliable dataset by cross-verifying automatic data with manual observations. This approach helps in addressing biases and errors inherent in automatic systems, particularly in remote and harsh environments like mountainous regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of long-term continuous soil parameter data and AWS measurements impact the understanding and modeling of hydrological processes in alpine catchments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating long-term continuous soil parameter data with AWS measurements enhances the understanding of hydrological processes by providing detailed insights into soil moisture dynamics and their interactions with other meteorological variables. It supports the development of distributed hydrological models that can more accurately simulate water balance and runoff in alpine regions, considering cryospheric and climatic influences.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes can arise from the deployment of specialized equipment like microlysimeters and sap flow sensors in mountain cryosphere areas for evaluating the effects of vegetation changes on water balance?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The deployment of equipment such as microlysimeters and sap flow sensors enables a detailed assessment of evapotranspiration and transpiration processes, which are crucial for understanding the effects of vegetation changes on water balance. It leads to a better comprehension of how changes in vegetation patterns influence river runoff and overall hydrology in mountainous regions, providing essential data for sustainable water management.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind obtaining comprehensive observation data about environmental factors in alpine regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on hydrology and water resources in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to employ diverse data collection methods involving meteorological variables and soil parameters in alpine catchments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Diverse data collection methods are important to address the challenges posed by the remoteness and sparse observations of these regions, and to provide reliable data for understanding cryospheric changes and their impacts.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can automated weather stations (AWS) be utilized to effectively monitor meteorological variables in alpine regions, and what are the key components involved in this data collection method?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Automated weather stations (AWS) can be effectively utilized in alpine regions by continuously monitoring meteorological variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. Key components involved in this data collection method include sensors for measuring these variables, such as SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors for snow depth and SI-111 infrared radiometers for land surface temperature, which are synchronized with the AWS.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in measuring soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in mountainous catchment areas, and how do these procedures contribute to understanding cryospheric hydrology?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Procedures involved in measuring soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in mountainous catchment areas include using single-ring and double-ring infiltrometers, Hood infiltrometers, and the ring cutter method. These procedures contribute to understanding cryospheric hydrology by providing insights into soil moisture dynamics and the interaction between soil water and surface runoff, which are critical for modeling hydrological processes in cryospheric environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: In the context of cryospheric hydrology, what methods can be employed to ensure accurate precipitation measurements, and what challenges might arise during this data collection process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methods to ensure accurate precipitation measurements in cryospheric hydrology include using total rain-weighing sensors with single alter shields, synchronized with AWS, and conducting precipitation intercomparisons with gauges such as pit gauges and double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauges. Challenges that might arise during this data collection process include significant biases and errors in precipitation observations due to the remote and harsh environment of alpine regions.

Enablement.Question: How do environmental observation systems address the challenges of sparse data collection in remote mountainous areas?
Enablement.Answer: Environmental observation systems such as AWS and stream-gauging stations, along with manual observations, are implemented to overcome the challenges of sparse data collection. These systems provide comprehensive datasets by combining automated and manual methods to cover various environmental parameters, despite the remoteness of the regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for environmental factors in mountainous regions face significant challenges and what are the potential solutions?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding changes in remote and vulnerable mountainous regions is challenging due to their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are particularly prone to biases and errors. One potential solution includes the use of automated weather stations (AWS) for long-term monitoring, supplemented by standard meteorological field observations for improved accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: What do you think are the key challenges in obtaining reliable cryospheric hydrology data in remote mountainous regions, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable regions like mountainous areas poses significant challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are particularly beset with significant biases and errors. These challenges could be addressed by improving observation techniques, deploying more automated weather stations (AWS), and refining precipitation measurement tools to reduce biases and errors.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how comprehensive environmental data can be automatically collected and stored in remote cryospheric regions.
Assertion.Answer: The comprehensive environmental data from remote cryospheric regions can be automatically collected and stored using systems like the ENVIS integrated environmental observation system, which is deployed at observation points and uses automatic data acquisition systems to record variables such as temperature, humidity, wind, soil moisture, and more.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how researchers can effectively monitor cryospheric changes with sparse observational data.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers can effectively monitor cryospheric changes by employing long-term monitoring at automatic weather stations (AWS) and conducting manual observations for reference. They also use various sensor technologies and methods to gather continuous soil and meteorological data, which help address the challenges posed by sparse observations.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the impacts of cryospheric changes on river runoff are evaluated in mountainous regions.
Assertion.Answer: The impacts of cryospheric changes on river runoff are evaluated by obtaining comprehensive observation data about environmental factors, monitoring streamflow at catchment outlets, and applying distributed hydrological models that include cryospheric hydrology. This helps assess the effects of climate, cryosphere, and vegetation changes on water resources.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore various meteorological variables that are monitored in alpine regions and discuss the methods used for their long-term measurement.
Request/Directive.Answer: Meteorological variables monitored include air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. These are measured using Automatic Weather Stations (AWS), standard meteorological field manual observations, soil parameter data collection, infrared radiometer measurements, and various precipitation measurement techniques.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges associated with collecting precipitation data in mountainous regions and discuss the methods used to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting precipitation data in mountainous regions include significant biases and errors due to the remoteness and sparse observations. Methods to address these challenges involve using pit gauges, a double reference intercomparison gauge, rain-weighing sensors synchronized with AWS, and conducting intercomparisons with international standards like the WMO Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and analyze the techniques used for groundwater and stream water sampling and monitoring in alpine catchments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Techniques for groundwater and stream water sampling include the installation of cluster wells for groundwater monitoring and sampling, and the collection of stream water samples from multiple sites. Groundwater samples are used for isotope analysis, while stream water samples are collected to study spatial distribution from upstream to downstream.
